content.description: Jump/hop start into a jug match, edgy foot work with a dash of smearing, solid leaning and a sketchy top out. Most difficult part is leaning without falling and effectively using your feet though it's still a V1
content.location: The route is near the river, while most go left at the headway to where the river breaks most go right down a rocky path to find a secluded little alcove, the rock is behind some foliage along the river's bank.

content.description: Fun movement, just make sure you bring a solid spotter and a crash pad. Start with a high left hand and a right on the crimp, traverse to the right and then top out. The crux is a stellar heel hook (I'll let you figure out the rest). Although the start is not very difficult, you can not quite get a crash pad below the climber until they make the first move. The pad sits on a rock directly below the climber forcing their feet to stay high the whole time. Easy walk off
content.location: From the parking lot hike to the boulders, go upstream about 40-50yds. The boulder is right next to a big tree near a small pool of water about 30-40yds away from the main flow of the creek. If you've made it to Faking Twosday you've just passed it.

content.description: Two for one special! Easier/juggy top out straight up(V1), or a pocket traverse to the right (V1-2)Â
content.location: Go to the end of the Avenue of Boulders trail, and continue following the river upstream. There's a large cliff (full of great cracks by the way) with the words, "Faking Tuesday" tagged onto it (NOT by me!!). Looking away from the graffiti, towards the river will reveal several amazing boulders. If you get to the bridge you walked too far.

content.description: An easy hike with majestic waterfalls, once you go down the trail from the obvious parking lot and follow the trail signs to the Valley of the Boulders you will find a respectable amount of climbs for Southwestern Oregon bouldering.
